More About Me

I am a full stack product designer and manager working out of Silicon Valley. I am fond of exploring and discovering great stories across all mediums. I apply this passion to my work as a means to engage with my users and stakeholders.

Oh, and I enjoy wearing red shoes as well.

Everything about me is a venn diagram and it helps me be well rounded. One of the key reasons for being a venn diagram is that I was raised on the sciences but always carried an innate passion for the creative arts, appreciating both equally.

This varied perspective gives me the confidence to experiment and broaden my horizons. I think its good to challenge yourself and not get boxed in as the business landscape moves fast and its good to always be willing to pivot.

My Ideal Process

It’s rare that a project would involve all of these steps but it doesn’t hurt for me to dream. Here is how I would run an ideal project would run from a full stack design perspective.

  • 1.Talk to internal stakeholders
  • 2.Review any existing documentation
  • 3.Interview real world users
  • 4. Document the pain points
  • 5. Create a journey map or storyboard
  • 6. Create a user flow and iterate with stakeholders
  • 7.Craft my story how the product would solve problems
  • 8.Translate the above materials to low fidelity wireframes
  • 9.Iterate wireframes with key stakeholders
  • 10.Convert static page wireframes to an interactive prototype
  • 11.Test prototype with real world users
  • 12.Iterate interactive prototype based on real world feedback
  • 13.Convert low fidelity wireframe assets to high fidelity assets
  • 14.Perform final review with stakeholders and iterate if needed
  • 15.Add notations where necessary to high fidelity prototype
  • 16.Document missing microinteractions
  • 17.Handoff to developers the high fidelity prototype and documentation
